description: From Low German knapzak or Dutch knapzak (older form cnapsack), from Middle Dutch cnappen (“to bite with teeth”), ultimately from knappen (“to eat, crack”), of imitative origin, + sack. German Knappsack is from Dutch.

entries.meaning: (chiefly US) A case of canvas or leather, for carrying items on the back.
(cryptography) A set of values from which a subset is chosen.

verbs.description: knapsack (third-person singular simple present knapsacks, present participle knapsacking, simple past and past participle knapsacked)

entries.meaning: To go hiking while burdened with a knapsack, usually overnight or for longer.
examples: My sleeping bag fell off my backpack into the water, while we were knapsacking up the mountain.
